thread.title: Australian dollar slides as scepticism over China persists despite policy moves
thread.title_full: Australian dollar slides as scepticism over China persists despite policy moves

title: Australian dollar slides as scepticism over China persists despite policy moves
text:
Just as a rally on Wall Street reversed, so began the selling of the Australian dollar.
Euphoria from a relief rally in global sharemarkets faded on Wednesday, bringing the Australian dollar down as much as a cent-and-a-half as more questions than answers emerged from China's decision to cut interest rates.
The Aussie reached a high of US72.50¢ overnight, spurred by news that the People's Bank of China had cut the nation's interest rates by 25 basis points to 4.6 per cent and reserve requirement ratios, the amount of cash required to be held by banks by 50 basis points to 18 per cent.
I expect the Aussie will remain under pressure for the foreseeable future.
Stephen Innes, OANDA Just as a rally on Wall Street reversed, so began the selling of 'risky' assets including the Australian dollar. Shortly before local markets opened the dollar hit the day's low of US70.98¢ as a lack of confidence crept back in the market.
A speech by Glenn Stevens on Wednesday added some support to the Aussie. Photo: Louie Douvis
Commonwealth Bank of Australia currency strategist Joseph Capurso said the trading was sparked by fresh concerns over China's economy.
Advertisement "If PBOC are still easing policy then that means there must be something wrong with the economy, hence selling down the Aussie," he said.
Stephen Innes, a senior trader at OANDA said it would take "a lot more than a local interest rate cut to shake local traders' pessimism about China's economy".
The dollar shed 1.5 cents overnight as relief from China turned to scepticism Photo: Bloomberg
"I expect the Aussie will remain under pressure for the foreseeable future," he said.
A speech by Reserve Bank of Australia governor Glenn Stevens on Wednesday morning added some support to the Aussie, giving it a leg up from the day's low to US71.27¢.
Mr Stevens' brief speech, albeit vague, was less dovish than anticipated, scaring the currency bears, ThinkForex senior market analyst Matt Simpson said.
Stability from Asian markets, with both the Shanghai and Tokyo exchanges trading in positive territory, added stability to the currency. In late trade the Aussie was fetching US71.24¢.
Better-than-expected local construction work done data also added support, Mr Capurso said.
Traders would be watching Thursday's business spending numbers. If they also surprised on the upside that may push the dollar back towards the US72¢ handle, but the overall momentum was downwards, he said.
